contentrichtext.text: A '''fakaleiti''' (or ''leiti'' or ''fakafefine'' or ''lady'') is a [[Tonga]]n [[male]] who behaves in a relatively effeminate manner. Although fakaleiti in Tonga do not necessarily associate with transgender or gay and lesbian identities in the Western world, those who grow up in Tongan migrant communities in New Zealand, Australia, and the United States may find a greater level of community and affinity to similar identities than fakaleiti in the island kingdom. The term ''fakaleiti'' (with a long ''i'' at the end) is made up of the prefix ''faka-'' (in the manner of) and the borrowing ''lady'' from English. ''Fakaleiti''s themselves prefer to call themselves ''leiti'' or ''ladies''. Fakaleiti or fakafefine are similar to Samoan [[fa'afafine]] and Hawaiian [[Mahu (person)|mahu]]. == See also == * [[Miss Galaxy Pageant]] * [[List of transgender-related topics]] == References == * {{cite book | last=Besnier |first= Niko |year= 1994 |chapter= Polynesian Gender Liminality Through Time and Space | title=Third Sex, Third Gender: Beyond Sexual Dimorphism in Culture and History | editor1-first=Gilbert | editor1-last= Herdt |pages= 285–328 |location= New York |publisher= Zone | isbn= 978-0-942299-82-3 }} * {{cite journal | doi=10.1080/00141844.1997.9981542 | last1=Besnier |first1= Niko |year= 1997 |title= Sluts and Superwomen: The Politics of Gender Liminality in Urban Tonga | journal = Ethnos |volume= 62 |pages=5–31 }} * {{cite journal | last1=Besnier |first1= Niko |year= 2002 |title= Transgenderism, Locality, and the Miss Galaxy Beauty Pageant in Tonga | journal = American Ethnologist |volume= 29 | pages = 534–566 | doi = 10.1525/ae.2002.29.3.534 }} * {{cite journal | last1=Besnier |first1= Niko |year= 2004 |title= The Social Production of Abjection: Desire and Silencing Among Transgender Tongans |journal = Social Anthropology | volume = 12 |pages=301–323 | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8676.2004.tb00110.x }} * {{cite journal | last1=James |first1= Kerry E. |year= 1994 |title= Effeminate Males and Changes in the Construction of Gender in Tonga | journal = Pacific Studies |volume= 17 |issue=2 |pages=39–69 | url = http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/PacificStudies,218 }} == External links == * [http://www.guidemag.com/magcontent/invokemagcontent.cfm?ID=4CFE923C-4559-4468-B8017560C17A353B The Guide - Fingering Machismo] [[Category:Gender in Oceania]] [[Category:Tongan culture]] [[Category:Third gender]] [[Category:Transgender in Oceania]] [[Category:Transgender identities]] {{Sexual identities}}
